title: Land values fall in Australia's most expensive markets
text:
Land values have slumped across the most expensive markets in the country over the past 12 months led by Sydney, with a 12.6 per cent decline in price per square metre, the latest HIA-CoreLogic Residential Land Report shows.

Prices in Adelaide also sank by 12 per cent, Melbourne fell by 7.4 per cent and Brisbane by 4.6 per cent.

The land shortage of the past five years has been met by supply. Getty

HIA economist Angela Lillicrap said weak buyer sentiment over the past two years caused the poor showing.

"Consumers were worried about the general health of the property market so there was a lot of hesitation to buy, which contributed to lower sales price in Sydney, Melbourne and Brisbane," she said.

"In addition, the land shortage that we've seen over the last five years has been met with supply, so prices have started coming down. Now, the market is in balance.
description: Sydney leads slump with 12.6 per cent decline, new HIA-CoreLogic data shows.
